title: Business investment points to 'good news'
text:
"Business investment in Australia is back to where it was in the mid-2000s – that is, it’s back to where it was before the resources boom, rather than back at early 1990s levels."

In real terms, business investment as a share of GDP is about 12 per cent; it was 6 per cent during the 1990s recession.

Other economists such as HSBC's Paul Bloxham also expect the level of business investment in some areas of the economy to compensate for a decline in investment in the dwelling and construction sector.

Non-mining business investment

"Our estimates show the expected growth in infrastructure and mining investment should be sufficient to offset the impact of the expected fall in housing construction over coming quarters," Mr Bloxham said.

Commonwealth Bank economists Belinda Allen and Kristina Clifton noted on Friday that the growth in non-mining business investment had been rising for several years now, but looked to have reached a plateau.

"The ABS capex survey suggests that non-mining business investment will continue to grow in 2019-20 but at a slower pace than recent years. The lift in investment should be broad-based across the states."

In the minutes of its September board meeting, the Reserve Bank also pointed to the positive elements of business investment.

"Overall, Australian businesses had not appeared to have been affected by the weak trade environment to the same extent as businesses in other advanced economies," it said.

"The ABS capital expenditure survey suggested that mining investment had grown in the June quarter, driven by an increase in machinery and equipment investment.

"The capex survey suggested there had also been an increase in machinery and equipment investment by the non-mining sector in the June quarter, while non-residential construction was expected to have declined."

Following the central bank's move to cut interest rates to a record 0.75 per cent this month, RBA governor Philip Lowe had said banks "should not be so scared" to lend to small business.

"It is important that our financial institutions support small businesses in particular. Lenders should not be so scared of making a loan that goes bad that they don’t provide the credit that the economy needs," he said.

While business investment may look better in inflation-adjusted terms, Deloitte does suggest in its outlook that the retail sector is a concern.

"Retail spending growth looks recessionary in inflation-adjusted terms," the report said, "but on the other hand retail price growth is now at its fastest in a decade".
description: Fears of a business investment strike have been exaggerated – spending is at more than twice the level during the 1990s recession, new analysis shows.
